title: MAIA Personal Lines Practice Exam 2 (Optimized)
description: A second set of 50 distinct practice questions covering the MAIA Personal Lines curriculum, balanced to match the official exam's emphasis on exclusion-based questioning.

questions.question: Which characteristic of an insurance contract allows a court to interpret ambiguous language in favor of the insured?
questions.explanation: Chapter 1-2 states that an insurance policy is a contract of adhesion ('drafted by the insurer'). Therefore, 'any language that is confusing... may be decided by a court in favor of the person who did not draft the language (i.e., the insured).'
questions.distractor_logic: Option A refers to unequal value exchange. Option B refers to one party making a promise. Option D refers to contract performance depending on certain conditions.

questions.question: All of the following statements regarding a Stock Insurer are true EXCEPT:

options.B: They are owned by their policyholders
options.C: They pay dividends to stockholders, not policyholders

questions.explanation: Stock insurers are owned by stockholders. Mutual insurers are the ones owned by policyholders. Therefore, the statement that stock insurers are owned by policyholders is the exception (false statement).
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, C, and D are all accurate descriptions of a Stock Insurer. Option B describes a Mutual Insurer.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT considered one of the three primary types of producer authority?
questions.explanation: The three types of authority are Express (written), Implied (incidental), and Apparent (perceived). 'Fiduciary Authority' is not a standard category of authority; fiduciary is a type of responsibility or capacity, not a source of authority.
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and C are the three recognized legal sources of an agent's authority.

questions.question: Installing a sprinkler system to minimize the severity of a fire loss is an example of which risk management technique?
questions.explanation: Chapter 2-2 and 2-14 classify installing a sprinkler system as Risk Reduction, which 'lessen[s] the severity of losses' rather than preventing them entirely.
questions.distractor_logic: Option A involves avoiding the activity entirely. Option B involves insurance. Option D involves paying for the loss oneself.

questions.question: Loss of rental income following a fire damage to an apartment building is best described as what type of loss?
questions.explanation: Chapter 2-4 defines Indirect Loss (or consequential loss) as 'associated with a loss of use,' such as 'loss of rent (rental value) or loss of use' resulting from a direct physical loss.
questions.distractor_logic: Option A refers to the physical damage itself. Option C refers to the cause. Option D is synonymous with direct loss to tangible property.

questions.question: Which type of damages are awarded to an injured party for intangible losses such as pain and suffering?
questions.explanation: Chapter 3-4 defines General Damages as 'those awarded for intangible types of loss that are non-economic or non-measurable such as pain and suffering.'
questions.distractor_logic: Option A (Special damages) are for tangible economic losses like medical bills. Option C (Punitive damages) are to punish the offender. Option D is not a standard term.

questions.question: Liability imposed on a parent for the actions of their minor child is known as:
questions.explanation: Chapter 3-5 defines Vicarious Liability as liability where one party is responsible for another, explicitly stating: 'A parent is vicariously liable for damage done by their minor children.'
questions.distractor_logic: Options A and B refer to liability without fault for dangerous activities. Option D is a defense against negligence.

questions.question: Under the DP-2 Broad Form, the 'Falling Objects' peril covers damage to the interior of a building ONLY if:

options.A: The object weighs more than 50 pounds
options.B: The exterior of the building is damaged first, creating an opening
options.C: The object is a tree branch
options.D: The insured is not at home

questions.explanation: Chapter 4-8 states regarding the Falling Objects peril in the DP-2: 'not interior damage unless exterior damage is done to a structure' (i.e., creating an opening).
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, C, and D are not conditions found in the policy text for this peril.

questions.question: The 'Trees, Shrubs, and Other Plants' coverage in a DP-2 policy provides a maximum per-item limit of:
questions.explanation: Chapter 4-6 states that the DP-2 trees, shrubs, and plants extension has 'a further limitation of $500 per damaged item.'
questions.distractor_logic: Option A is a standard deductible. Option C is the tree removal limit for windstorm in Homeowners. Option D is a limit for business property.

questions.question: Which of the following is excluded under the Vandalism coverage in a DP-1 policy?

options.B: Damage occurring after 30 days of vacancy

questions.explanation: Chapter 4-5 states regarding DP-1 Vandalism: 'V & MM does not cover glass breakage or loss by theft.'
questions.distractor_logic: Option B is incorrect; the vacancy exclusion is 60 days. Options A and D are generally covered perils if V&MM is purchased.

questions.question: If a Homeowners policy (HO-3) provides $300,000 in coverage on the dwelling, what is the additional amount of insurance available for Debris Removal if the actual damage plus debris removal exceeds the policy limit?
questions.explanation: Chapter 5-4 states: 'If there were a total loss to the dwelling, the policy will provide debris removal in an additional amount of 5% of the dwelling limit.'
questions.distractor_logic: Option A is incorrect because there is an additional amount. Options C and D are incorrect percentages/figures.

questions.question: What is the special limit of liability for theft of firearms in a Homeowners policy?
questions.explanation: Chapter 5-3 lists the Special Limits of Liability: '$2,500 for loss by theft of firearms.'
questions.distractor_logic: Option A ($1,500) is for jewelry/furs. Option D is for grave markers. Option B is not a standard limit.

questions.question: Under the 'Pair and Set' clause, if one earring from a pair valued at $2,000 is lost, and the remaining earring is worth $600, how will the insurer settle the loss (assuming they do not repair/replace)?
questions.explanation: Chapter 5-6 states the insurer may 'pay the difference between the ACV of the property before and after the loss.' ($2,000 value of set - $600 remaining value = $1,400 loss).
questions.distractor_logic: Option A is the full value. Option B assumes a 50/50 split. Option D is incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following would NOT be covered under Section II (Liability) of a Homeowners policy?

options.A: Injury to a guest who slips on the insured's walkway
options.B: Damage to a neighbor's window caused by the insured's child
options.C: Injury to the named insured caused by falling down their own stairs
options.D: Injury caused by the insured's dog

questions.explanation: Chapter 5-8 states that Section II coverage 'do[es] not apply to any insured or resident relative.' Liability coverage is for third parties, not the insured.
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D involve third-party losses which are covered.

questions.question: Damage to property of others caused by an insured is covered under the 'Damage to Property of Others' additional coverage up to what amount?
questions.explanation: Chapter 5-9 states regarding additional coverages: 'Damage to the property of others is also provided for up to $1,000.'
questions.distractor_logic: Option B ($500) is the limit for Fire Department Service Charge. Option D ($2,500) is for landlord's furnishings.

questions.question: Which policy form is intended for a tenant renting an apartment?
questions.explanation: Chapter 5-14 identifies the HO-4 as the 'Contents Broad Form' or 'Tenants Broad Form,' which provides coverage for a renter's personal property.
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D are forms for owner-occupants of dwellings.

questions.question: Power failure is excluded under the Homeowners policy unless:

options.A: The failure occurs on the insured premises
options.B: The failure lasts more than 24 hours
options.C: The failure causes a covered peril (like fire) to occur on the premises
options.D: The insured pays an extra premium

questions.explanation: Chapter 5-5 lists 'power failure off the premises' as excluded. However, if a power failure off-premises causes a covered peril (such as fire or explosion) to occur on the residence premises, the resulting damage from that covered peril is covered.
questions.distractor_logic: Option A is the inverse of the exclusion text (power failure ON premises is generally not a peril in itself, but the exclusion specifically targets OFF premises failure). Option B is a time element not in the text.

questions.question: Under the MA Personal Auto Policy, which vehicle is NOT considered a 'Private Passenger Auto'?

options.A: A station wagon owned by an individual
options.B: A pickup truck used for delivery of goods in a business
options.C: A van leased for 12 months used for personal transportation
options.D: A jeep owned by two individuals

questions.explanation: The Auto Policy Definitions section states a pickup or van is excluded if 'used for delivery or transportation of goods or materials unless such use is incidental to the insured's business of installing...'. Regular delivery use disqualifies it.
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, C, and D fit the definition of eligible private passenger autos (owned/leased by individuals, personal use).

questions.question: What percentage of lost wages does Personal Injury Protection (PIP) pay?
questions.explanation: The Auto Policy Part II (PIP) section states: 'The policy will pay up to 75% of an injured person's average weekly gross wage.'
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D are incorrect percentages for the lost wage benefit in MA PIP.

questions.question: Part 3 (Uninsured Motorist) covers bodily injury caused by a 'hit-and-run' driver only if:

options.A: The driver is identified within 24 hours
options.B: There is physical contact with the vehicle
options.C: The responsible driver cannot be identified
options.D: The accident occurs on private property

questions.explanation: The Auto Policy Part III section states: 'Coverage against hit-and-run drivers is provided if the responsible driver cannot be identified.'
questions.distractor_logic: Option B (physical contact) is a requirement in some states but the text emphasizes identification. Option A is not a condition. Option D is irrelevant.

questions.question: Which optional auto coverage pays for bail bonds if the insured is arrested due to an accident?
questions.explanation: The Auto Policy Part V section states: 'Part V also includes coverage for bail bonds up to $250 if the insured or a family member is arrested as a result of an auto accident.'
questions.distractor_logic: Part 1 covers premiums for appeal bonds but not bail bonds. Parts 6 and 11 do not cover bonds.

questions.question: Part 6 (Medical Payments) of the MA Auto Policy will NOT pay for expenses incurred:

options.A: More than two years after the accident
options.B: By a pedestrian struck by the auto
options.C: By a passenger in the auto

questions.explanation: The Auto Policy Part VI section states: 'The insurer will not pay for expenses incurred more than two years after the date of the accident.'
questions.distractor_logic: Options B, C, and D are all covered under Medical Payments.

questions.question: In Massachusetts, the optional deductible for glass damage under Comprehensive coverage is typically:
questions.explanation: The Auto Policy Part IX section states: 'Also, a $100 glass damage deductible is optional.'
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, C, and D are other deductible amounts or misconceptions, but $100 is explicitly cited for glass.

questions.question: After an auto policy has been in effect for 90 days, an insurer can cancel for all of the following reasons EXCEPT:

options.C: Failure to pay surcharge for moving violations

questions.explanation: The Auto Policy Cancellation section lists valid reasons after 90 days: nonpayment, license suspension, failure to pay surcharges, and fraud. 'Involvement in two not-at-fault accidents' is NOT a valid reason.
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and C are explicitly listed as valid reasons for cancellation.

questions.question: If an insurer requires a pre-insurance inspection for physical damage coverage, it may defer the inspection for how many calendar days?
questions.explanation: The Auto Policy section on Pre-Insurance Inspections states: 'In some cases the insurer may defer the required inspection of the auto for ten (10) calendar days.'
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D are incorrect timeframes for this specific regulation.

questions.question: Under the MA Auto Policy, a collision with a bird or animal is covered under:
questions.explanation: The Auto Policy Part IX section states: 'The perils covered by this part include... collision with a bird or animal.'
questions.distractor_logic: Collision coverage (Part 7) explicitly excludes collision with animals (referring them to Comprehensive).

questions.question: Before an insurer issues a personal umbrella policy, they will typically require the insured to maintain:
questions.explanation: Chapter 7-1 states: 'Specific limits of underlying liability insurance must be purchased before an insurer will permit an insured to purchase umbrella coverage.' (e.g., $300,000 auto limits).
questions.distractor_logic: Options A and D are not universal requirements mentioned. Option C is for commercial umbrellas.

questions.question: For a flood to be covered under an NFIP policy, it must affect:

options.B: Two or more properties or two or more acres of land
options.D: At least 50% of the insured's land

questions.explanation: Chapter 8-2 defines a covered flood: 'A covered flood must be a general condition... However, two or more properties or two or more acres of land must be affected.'
questions.distractor_logic: Option A is incorrect (must be general condition). Option C is too broad. Option D is not the specific threshold.

questions.question: Under the NFIP Emergency Program, what is the maximum coverage limit for a single-family residential dwelling?
questions.explanation: Chapter 8-2, Limits of Coverage table, lists the Emergency Program limit for a Single family residential dwelling as '$35,000'.
questions.distractor_logic: Option C ($100,000) is the Emergency limit for non-residential. Option D ($250,000) is the Regular Program limit.

questions.question: A Public Insurance (Fire) Adjuster represents:
questions.explanation: Chapter 9-1 defines a Public Insurance Adjuster as 'a person who represents a policyholder in the negotiation of a loss payable by a fire insurance policy.'
questions.distractor_logic: Option A is represented by a company adjuster. Options C and D are not the principals.

questions.question: A holder of a temporary license in Massachusetts may do all of the following EXCEPT:

options.D: Operate without passing the state exam (for a limited time)

questions.explanation: Chapter 9-3 explicitly states: 'This license does not allow the holder to write new business but only to receive renewal commissions.'
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D are permitted activities/characteristics of the temporary license.

questions.question: A producer must report any administrative action taken against them in another jurisdiction to the Commissioner within:
questions.explanation: Chapter 9-6 under Reporting of Actions states: 'A producer must report... within 30 days of a final disposition of the matter.'
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D are incorrect timeframes for this specific report.

questions.question: Making false statements about the financial condition of a competing insurer is an unfair trade practice known as:
questions.explanation: Chapter 9-15 defines Defamation as 'making false or untrue statements regarding a competing insurer... regarding the financial condition...'
questions.distractor_logic: Option A refers to policy replacement. Options B and D refer to restraint of trade.

questions.question: What is the maximum prison sentence for a producer convicted of embezzlement in Massachusetts?
questions.explanation: Chapter 9-15 states that a producer who embezzles funds 'will be subject to a prison sentence in State prison for a term of up to five (5) years.'
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D are incorrect sentencing limits for this specific crime.

questions.question: Under the Insurance Information and Privacy Protection Act, if an individual requests access to their personal information, the insurer must provide it within:
questions.explanation: Chapter 9-17 states: 'Once a request is made, the insurance organization must provide the individual with the information... within 30 days.'
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D are incorrect timeframes.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the inception of the Massachusetts Standard Fire Policy is FALSE?

options.A: The policy goes into effect at 12:01 AM
options.B: The policy goes into effect at 12:00 PM (Noon)
options.C: The time refers to standard time at the location of the property
options.D: The policy typically expires at 12:01 AM on the expiration date

questions.explanation: Chapter 9-18 states: 'Massachusetts standard fire policies will go into effect at 12:01 a.m. on the policy's inception date.' Therefore, the statement that it goes into effect at Noon (which was the old standard) is the FALSE statement.
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, C, and D are true statements regarding the policy term.

questions.question: Which term describes the 'binding force' of a policy, consisting of the premium and representations?
questions.explanation: Chapter 1-1 defines Consideration as the 'binding force of the policy' involving the exchange of value (premium/representations for promise to pay).
questions.distractor_logic: Option A is the meeting of minds. Option C is legal ability to contract. Option D is a guaranteed statement.

questions.question: All of the following statements regarding Hazards and Perils are true EXCEPT:

options.A: A Peril is the actual cause of a loss
options.B: A Hazard increases the likelihood of a loss
options.C: Fire is an example of a Hazard
options.D: Wet leaves on a sidewalk are an example of a Hazard

questions.explanation: Fire is a Peril (a cause of loss), not a Hazard. A Hazard is a condition that increases the chance of a peril occurring (e.g., faulty wiring). Therefore, classifying Fire as a Hazard is the false statement.
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D are correct definitions and examples.

questions.question: In a DP-3 Special Form, damage to personal property (Coverage C) is covered on which basis?
questions.explanation: Chapter 4-9 states regarding DP-3: 'Coverage C... is protected on a 'broad form peril' basis.' (Only Coverages A and B are open peril).
questions.distractor_logic: Option A applies to the dwelling only. Option C applies to DP-1. Option D applies to settlement, not perils.

questions.question: Which Homeowners form provides Open Peril coverage for BOTH the dwelling and personal property?
questions.explanation: Chapter 5-14 states: 'The HO-5 policy provides the broadest scope of coverage... since it provides coverage for real and personal property on an open peril basis.'
questions.distractor_logic: Option A (HO-3) is open peril on dwelling but named peril on contents. Options B and D are named peril forms.

questions.question: The definition of 'Occupying' in the MA Auto Policy includes all of the following EXCEPT:

options.C: Repairing the auto in a garage

questions.explanation: The Auto Policy Definitions section defines Occupying as 'being in or upon, entering in, or getting out of or 'alighting' from the auto.' Repairing in a garage is not included.
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D are explicitly included in the definition.

questions.question: An insurer may cancel collision coverage if the vehicle is designated as a 'high-theft vehicle' and:

options.B: Does not have a minimum anti-theft device
options.D: Is driven by a youthful operator

questions.explanation: The Auto Policy Cancellation section allows cancellation for a high-theft vehicle 'which does not have at least a minimum anti-theft or auto recovery device.'
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, C, and D are not valid reasons for canceling collision specifically under the high-theft provision.

questions.question: All of the following are distinct legal characteristics of an insurance contract EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Insurance contracts are Unilateral (only the insurer makes an enforceable promise), not Bilateral. Therefore, 'Bilateral' is the exception/false characteristic.
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D are all correct legal characteristics of insurance contracts.

questions.question: It is an unfair trade practice to advertise that a policy is covered by the:
questions.explanation: Chapter 9-17 states: 'it is also prohibited to unfairly advertise with regard to the Insurance Guaranty Fund.'
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D are not subject to this specific advertising prohibition in the text.

questions.question: In Massachusetts property insurance, if there is a delay in issuing a policy, a binder may be extended for up to:
questions.explanation: Chapter 9-19 states: 'if there is a delay in the issuance of a policy, a binder may be extended for up to 30 days.'
questions.distractor_logic: Option C (60 days) is mentioned in general terms in Chapter 2, but the MA specific section says 30 days.

questions.question: The right of the insurer to take title to damaged property after paying a total loss is called:
questions.explanation: The Auto Policy section on Salvage states: 'allows the insurer to take title to the damaged property if a total loss is paid... It may sell parts... to recoup part of the amount paid.'
questions.distractor_logic: Option A refers to recovering from a third party. Option C is generally prohibited. Option D is for dispute resolution.

questions.question: Under MA regulations, how many days notice must an insurer provide to a mortgagee if cancelling a policy?
questions.explanation: Chapter 9-20 and 9-21 state: 'If an insurer cancels a property insurance policy, it must provide a mortgagee or lienholder with 20 days written notice.'
questions.distractor_logic: Option A (10 days) is for non-renewal to mortgagee. Option D (45 days) is non-renewal to insured.

questions.question: Part 1 (Bodily Injury to Others) of the MA Auto Policy will pay for injuries to:

options.A: The driver of the insured auto
options.B: Guest occupants in the insured auto
options.C: Pedestrians struck by the insured auto in Massachusetts

questions.explanation: The Auto Policy Part I section states it will pay damages to people injured by your car in MA, but explicitly excludes: '(1) injuries to the driver or guest occupants... (3) injuries to any employee legally entitled to Workers' Compensation benefits.' Thus, pedestrians are the covered group.
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D are specific exclusions listed in the Part I text.

questions.question: Does a Flood Insurance policy cover the cost of removing trees and shrubs that have washed up on the insured premises?

options.C: No, Debris Removal is limited to covered property

questions.explanation: Chapter 8-2 states: 'Debris removal is covered but only for the cost incurred to remove the covered property. This would not include trees, shrubbery and any other materials that 'washed up'.'
questions.distractor_logic: Options A and B are incorrect interpretations of the Debris Removal clause in the NFIP policy.

questions.question: If an insurer pays for a loss using after-market parts (not made by the original manufacturer), they must:

options.B: Provide a discount on the deductible
options.C: Provide notice to the insured in the estimate

questions.explanation: The Auto Policy section on After Market Parts states: 'it must provide to an insured in an estimate for damage, a notice stating that the repair estimate is based in part on the use of replacement parts...'
questions.distractor_logic: Options A, B, and D are not requirements listed in the text.
